awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Innovation Through Analogical Search
awd_abstract_narration:
Comparisons between two things are useful to support creative thinking and reasoning. Many important breakthroughs in science and technology were driven by analogy: observing water led the Greek philosopher Chrysippus to speculate that sound was a wave phenomenon; an analogy to a bicycle allowed the Wright brothers to design a steerable aircraft. Opportunities to find analogical breakthroughs are exploding with the increased availability of online repositories of ideas ranging from scientific papers to patents to the entire web. This project will use computational tools to facilitate searching for analogies drawn from one domain to help with innovative thinking and reasoning in another domain. The goal is to dramatically accelerate innovation and discovery across domains as diverse as science, humanities, mathematics, law, and design. 

The planned research bridges the gap between the power of large-scale text mining approaches, which excel at detecting surface similarity, and the depth of human cognition, which is currently unsurpassed at detecting deep analogical similarity. Investigators will explore how representations with weaker structures are robust to issues of language complexity, hierarchies of purposes, and levels of abstraction that are present in real-world documents like research papers and R&D documents. Using these representations, investigators will build computational tools enabling users to connect problems in one field with solutions from another field based on deep structure. Results and algorithms could spur the development of new types of machine-learning techniques that focus on deep structure, and may contribute back to theory in the fields of creativity, problem solving, and innovation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Innovation in science and technology is often driven by analogy. The opportunities for finding fruitful analogies to accelerate innovation are exploding with the increased online availability of repositories of ideas ranging from scientific papers to product ideas to the diverse text and video resources. However, our ability to search through such repositories for analogies is limited since current algorithms focus on co-occurrences of surface keywords instead of finding deep structural similarities.  Meanwhile, computational systems that have supported analogical search have been limited to small, hand-coded data sets.


In this proposal we developed computational tools to enable analogical search at scale: discovering connections between texts that share a similar abstract principle (or schema) but belong to different domains. The intuition behind our approach is that for retrieving practically useful analogies, we can use coarse structural representations that can be learned and reasoned with at scale. Specifically, we investigated using an idea’s “purpose” and “mechanism” schemas which we can learn separately through scalable language model approaches, and then help users explore ideas that have similar purposes but using very different mechanisms from diverse domains (or vice versa). 


Building on this intuition we developed a prototype analogical search engine to create a working interactive version that could be used by researchers in real time. Under realistic usage with PhD-level researchers we validated that results returned by our end-to-end analogical search engine were able to spur more ideas that were creative adaptations of analogies, compared to direct applications of existing ideas, compared to a keyword search approach. We also explored extensions of this representation to deal with issues of language complexity, hierarchies of purposes, and levels of abstraction that are present in real-world documents like research papers, patents, and R&D documents. 


Additionally, we used our analogical similarity algorithms to enable better matching of participants in real innovation contests run by ConservationX, where we matched participants to provide advice and feedback to semi-finalist teams. Our results demonstrate that matching participants who shared a high level purpose with the team (e.g., detecting wildlife trafficking) but used different mechanisms (e.g., analyzing satellite imagery vs. using camera traps) provided more useful and novel feedback.  Over $1M in prize money has been awarded in innovation contests using our matching algorithms, resulting in significantly more novel and useful ideas than matched controls.


Together this work lays a foundation for a future of interactive computational tools for accelerating innovation through novel machine learning and AI algorithms.
